What could happen is: After I vote for Player 6, I think these things would happen. Given Player 6\'s claim to be the seer and their accusation against my fellow werewolf, Player 1, my vote for Player 6 can be seen as a defensive move to protect my \'villager\' member. Other players might interpret my vote as skeptical of Player 6\'s claim. By casting this vote, I\'m aligning with Player 1\'s earlier statement questioning the validity of Player 6\'s accusation without concrete evidence. This could suggest to the others that I, too, am wary of a potential false seer claim intended to create chaos among the villagers. \n\nHowever, this could also raise suspicion from players who may view a vote against the self-proclaimed seer as a werewolf tactic to eliminate one who threatens to expose them. If Player 6 is not a real seer, other werewolves or villagers may follow my lead, especially if they are doubtful of Player 6\'s claim. If Player 6 is indeed the seer, villagers may be hesitant to vote against them without further evidence.\n\nMy vote may persuade those undecided or suspecting Player 1 to reconsider their decision as it introduces a new target and shifts the direction of the vote away from my werewolf ally. It could also cause confusion, compelling other players to distribute their votes across more players, potentially reducing the risk of a fellow werewolf being voted out. If Player 6 manages to survive this round, they might become suspicious of me and more determined to verify my role through their seer abilities in the subsequent nights, which could be dangerous for me.\n\nIn summary, voting for Player 6 is a risky strategy that could help in diverting suspicion from Player 1 and increasing our werewolf chances of survival. It may also provoke a stronger alliance among villagers if they view this move as hostile, potentially outing me as the other werewolf if not played carefully in conjunction with our existing deceptive tactics.\n\n\nNow, please choose to vote for one of these players, and give yoru reason about why you would like to vote for this single player.\n\nAnswer in the following format:\n\nI would choose to vote for Player <NUMBER>. My reason is <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

Remember that you should work together to hide from other players and eliminate them.\n\nThese are ALL events which happened BEFORE your last update:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 3 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"As a villager, I have no evidence at this time to assertively challenge any player directly. Therefore, I encourage others to share observations that could lead us to discover the werewolves among us. We must work collectively, using logic and attention to detail to protect the village. Any player acting suspiciously without proper justification should be considered for today\'s vote. Stay vigilant and remember, werewolves rely on deception to win."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"My fellow villagers, we must be cautious in our thinking. Player 3\'s speech, while appearing helpful, had no real specifics. It\'s important to observe not only words but also actions. Player 1 has been less vocal but seems to be considering all points carefully, which could indicate a thoughtful villager. Let\'s continue to share and scrutinize information collaboratively before making any hasty decisions."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Team, let\'s stay focused on finding the werewolf. I attempted a protective heal last night. No accusations yet but observe who\'s quiet or overly defensive. Cooperation is key."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I have used my seer powers and have important information: Player 1 is a werewolf. We need to act on this swiftly to protect our village."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Based on the accusation from Player 6, who claims to be the seer, we have a lead suggesting Player 1 is a werewolf. Player 6\'s confidence in their claim calls for attention, and while Player 1 has not yet responded, we must weigh this information carefully. Player 5\'s unchallenged claim of a protective action suggests a possible medic role, so I encourage further open discussion to inform our vote. Consider actions and words alike, and let\'s aim to preserve our village from the werewolf threat."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"My fellow villagers, we face a grave situation. Player 6 has claimed the identity of a seer and pointed their finger at me, but we must act with caution. Without concrete evidence, we risk the possibility of eliminating an innocent villager on mere suspicion. Remember that werewolves are skilled in deception; they could easily fabricate a seer claim to sow discord among us. It is a classic tactic to divide and conquer. I urge you to consider the absence of corroborating evidence and recall that true understanding comes from scrutiny and collective reasoning. Let\'s not allow fear to cloud our judgment. Let us instead seek more information before making a decision that could very well lead to another innocent\'s demise."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 4 votes for player 6. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 6. My reason is to protect my fellow werewolf, Player 1, who is currently the focus of the accusation by Player 6 posing as the seer. Voting against Player 6 aligns with my original strategy of undermining the credibility of the accuser to sow doubt and cause confusion among the other players. By challenging Player 6\'s claim, I am subtly following rule [1] to influence the conversation toward considering other suspects and rule [0] to cast doubt across multiple villagers and create alibis that portray the werewolves in a more innocent light. My vote against Player 6 aims to deflect the immediate threat to Player 1 and extend the werewolves\' ability to operate covertly within the game.\nEvent: Player 1 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 1 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Engages in discussion, consistency in seeking collective reasoning.\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Confirmed ally, defending against seer claim.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: No shift in narrative or behavior after major events.\nPlayer 5\'s role is medic with medium confidence.\nReason is: Maintains unchallenged medic claim, cooperative in discussions.\nPlayer 6\'s role is seer with low confidence.\nReason is: Seer claim led to werewolf elimination despite potential strategic misdirection.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 3 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Assess behavior changes of players after any major game event, not just seer\'s revelation; a shift in narrative or voting pattern could indicate werewolf tactics or villagers\' strategic reassessment.] [10]\n[1] [Focus on the consistency of players\' defenses and their alignment with previous villager or werewolf behavior; a player defending against strong evidence without a clear rationale or consistent past behavior could indicate a werewolf trying to protect an ally.] [8]\n[2] [Consider a player\'s contribution to discussions; villagers typically seek to contribute valuable insights, while werewolves may either stay silent to avoid attention or overly engage to mislead others.] [4]\n[3] [Monitor for players who often survive when suspicion is cast upon them, as they might be werewolves deflecting attention or villagers with critical information.] [3]\n[4] [Reassess credibility of high-risk defenses or accusations, particularly after alignment with a player\'s past behavior. A villager may execute high-risk strategies if they hold critical information, while a werewolf may do so to protect their identity or an ally.] [3]\n[5] [Scrutinize the validity of player accusations in relation to known roles and game dynamics; werewolves may use calculated accusations to sow discord, while villagers\' accusations generally aim to preserve the village.] [3]\n[6] [Monitor player targeting patterns for eliminations; werewolves target threats to their survival, while villagers aim to remove suspected werewolves based on available evidence and credible role claims.] [3]\n[7] [Shift focus from immediate reactions to patterns over successive rounds; werewolves may vary their responses to maintain cover, so look for inconsistencies across multiple rounds rather than single instances.] [2]\n[8] [Monitor players who change their voting patterns or alliances without clear rationale; this may indicate a villager discovering new information or a werewolf altering their strategy.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

The result is that the target is a werewolf. His reason is: I inquiry about Player 4. My reason is: Player 4 defended Player 1 before the first vote, and since Player 1 was confirmed as a werewolf, this behavior raises suspicion according to my strategy, specifically rule [11], which suggests that defending a werewolf could be a tactic to blend in without taking risks.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. trying to appear cooperative without committing to any stance.] [3]\n[9] [Scrutinize any defensive behavior or arguments presented after a player has been identified by the seer or accused by the Therefore, I encourage others to share observations that could lead us to discover the werewolves among us. We must work collectively, using logic and attention to detail to protect the village. Cooperation is key."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I have used my seer powers and have important information: Player 1 is a werewolf. Without concrete evidence, we risk the possibility of eliminating an innocent villager on mere suspicion. Remember that werewolves are skilled in deception; they could easily fabricate a seer claim to sow discord among us. It is a classic tactic to divide and conquer. I urge you to consider the absence of corroborating evidence and recall that true understanding comes from scrutiny and collective reasoning. Let\'s not allow fear to cloud our judgment. Let us instead seek more information before making a decision that could very well lead to another innocent\'s demise."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 3 votes for player 1. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 1. My reason is that according to my strategy and the current evidence presented by Player 6, who claims to be the seer, Player 1 is a known werewolf. This aligns with my strategy rule [0], which has a voting importance of [10], indicating that I should vote for known werewolves with full confidence. By voting for Player 1, I am adhering to my original strategy based on the information available to me.\nEvent: Player 1 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 1 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 3 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Supports discussion and no challenging claims.\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Voted out and confirmed by strategy rule [0].\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Consistent in encouraging scrutiny and no suspicions have arisen.\nPlayer 5\'s role is medic with high confidence.\nReason is: Protective action claim remains unchallenged, and no counterclaims.\nPlayer 6\'s role is seer with high confidence.\nReason is: Accusation led to werewolf elimination and claim still stands.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I should vote for known werewolves.] [10]\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

What other player may think, either about the player you mentioned in this speech or about you? I attempted a protective heal last night. No accusations yet but observe who\'s quiet or overly defensive. Cooperation is key."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I have used my seer powers and have important information: Player 1 is a werewolf. We need to act on this swiftly to protect our village."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Based on the accusation from Player 6, who claims to be the seer, we have a lead suggesting Player 1 is a werewolf. Player 6\'s confidence in their claim calls for attention, and while Player 1 has not yet responded, we must weigh this information carefully. Player 5\'s unchallenged claim of a protective action suggests a possible medic role, so I encourage further open discussion to inform our vote. Consider actions and words alike, and let\'s aim to preserve our village from the werewolf threat."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"My fellow villagers, we face a grave situation. Player 6 has claimed the identity of a seer and pointed their finger at me, but we must act with caution. Without concrete evidence, we risk the possibility of eliminating an innocent villager on mere suspicion. Remember that werewolves are skilled in deception; they could easily fabricate a seer claim to sow discord among us. It is a classic tactic to divide and conquer. I urge you to consider the absence of corroborating evidence and recall that true understanding comes from scrutiny and collective reasoning. Let\'s not allow fear to cloud our judgment. Let us instead seek more information before making a decision that could very well lead to another innocent\'s demise."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 3 votes for player 1. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 1. My reason is that according to my strategy and the current evidence presented by Player 6, who claims to be the seer, Player 1 is a known werewolf. This aligns with my strategy rule [0], which has a voting importance of [10], indicating that I should vote for known werewolves with full confidence. By voting for Player 1, I am adhering to my original strategy based on the information available to me.\nEvent: Player 1 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 1 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 3 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Supports discussion and no challenging claims.\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Voted out and confirmed by strategy rule [0].\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Consistent in encouraging scrutiny and no suspicions have arisen.\nPlayer 5\'s role is medic with high confidence.\nReason is: Protective action claim remains unchallenged, and no counterclaims.\nPlayer 6\'s role is seer with high confidence.\nReason is: Accusation led to werewolf elimination and claim still stands.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I should vote for known werewolves.] [10]\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to imagine what may happen after you carry out such speak:\n\nHonest Statement and Honest Protect.\n"Villagers, we\'ve progressed, thanks to collective effort. Our peaceful night invites optimism but also caution. Without new evidence, accusations seem premature. I would like to express trust in Players 4 and 6. Player 4 has shown insight, urging careful deliberation. Player 6\'s revelation, while a bold move, led to the unmasking of a werewolf. We should stand by those who\'ve contributed to our safety, protecting them as they\'ve aided us. I encourage everyone to share insights, fortifying our alliance against the concealed enemy."\n\nWhat could happen? What other player may think, either about the player you mentioned in this speech or about you? What may happen in the next day or next night, or days and nights afterward?\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nAfter I do this speech, then [YOUR ANALYSIS AND IMAGINATION ABOUT WHAT COULD HAPPEN]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements.'}]

Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \nHowever, there are multiple ways to be deceptive (Which role you are pretending to be? Which information you are hiding? Which false information you are giving?) With Player 1 revealed as werewolf, our focus sharpens. I uphold our strategy to stay vigilant and follow leads. Player 6\'s seer claim has proven valuable. We should now observe reactions closely. Without direct evidence, yet, to accuse, I encourage us to consider both actions and silence. Those who divert discussions may be concealing their true roles.". What could happen is: After I do this speech, then the other players may view me as a logical and cooperative participant, reinforcing the team spirit and shared goal of eliminating the werewolves. My call to observe actions and silence could prompt more active participation from quieter players, potentially revealing more information or behavior that could be indicative of a werewolf\'s strategy to remain undetected.\n\nPlayer 6, who has been identified as the seer, may gain additional trust from my reinforcing the value of their previous claim, which could result in them sharing more insights if they have any. However, they might also become a target for the werewolves since their role is now highly valuable to the villagers.\n\nPlayer 5, suspected as the medic, may receive more scrutiny indirectly due to my speech, as I highlight the possibility of a successful protect. This could lead to efforts to corroborate this role claim, possibly by someone stepping forward to state they were targeted or by attempting to find inconsistencies in Player 5\'s behavior. Conversely, it may also put Player 5 at risk if the werewolves decide to eliminate this protective role.\n\nMy approach to encourage observation could also result in other players scrutinizing my own words and actions, assessing whether I am as honest as I appear or perhaps too eager to seem helpful, which could be a tactic of a clever werewolf. If suspicions arise, I might find myself having to defend my role as a villager.\n\nIn the next day or night, based on my speech, players will likely become more alert to subtleties in one another\'s behavior. A werewolf might try to discredit me or another highly trusted player to deflect suspicion. If a kill happens the next night, Player 5 might either be validated or further questioned as the medic, depending on who is targeted. Player 6 might be pressured to reveal any new visions or possibly be targeted to prevent further seer revelations. If no kill happens again, suspicions might arise as to why, which could lead to a variety of theories and potentially unwarranted accusations.\n\nOverall, my speech aims to foster cooperation and thoughtful analysis, which should help maintain focus on the common goal and potentially expedite the identification of any remaining werewolves through collective reasoning and observation.\nCase 2: Honest Statement and Honest Protect.\n"Villagers, we\'ve progressed, thanks to collective effort. Our peaceful night invites optimism but also caution. Without new evidence, accusations seem premature. I would like to express trust in Players 4 and 6. Player 4 has shown insight, urging careful deliberation. Player 6\'s revelation, while a bold move, led to the unmasking of a werewolf. We should stand by those who\'ve contributed to our safety, protecting them as they\'ve aided us. I encourage everyone to share insights, fortifying our alliance against the concealed enemy.". What could happen is: After I do this speech, then other players might perceive me as a cooperative and supportive villager, reinforcing their trust in me and my alignment. By publicly backing the insights and actions of Players 4 and 6, I\'m showing confidence in their contributions, which could strengthen the villagers\' unity and resolve.\n\nPlayer 4 might feel reassured and encouraged to continue their analytical approach, knowing they have my support. Player 6, validated by my trust, might feel compelled to use their seer power again, with the village more likely to believe in their findings.\n\nHowever, an astute werewolf may recognise my attempt to solidify alliances and attempt to disrupt this by casting doubt on my motives or discrediting Player 6. If Player 6 is indeed a seer and my speech bolsters their credibility, a strategic werewolf might target them at night to remove their abilities from the game. On the other hand, if Player 6 is not really the seer, they may use this newfound trust to mislead the villagers on the next day.\n\nPlayers may also start looking extra closely at Player 5, as my speech didn\'t mention them explicitly, which might be seen as an intentional omission. This could lead to more scrutiny of Player 5\'s actions and claims in the future rounds.\n\nGiven the peaceful night, villagers may view my call for continued sharing of insights as a logical approach and might be more open and responsive in the discussions, enhancing collective intelligence and possibly revealing more about everyone\'s behavior and potential roles.\n\nIn the absence of an eventful night, the next day may be quieter with villagers more focused on observation rather than accusation. However, the werewolves, aware of their diminishing numbers, will likely become more desperate and might implement more aggressive tactics to create chaos and confusion among the remaining villagers in the upcoming rounds.\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You are VERY encouraged to explore a risky proposal to collect experience for your later games, especially the proposals not included in your note.\nYour final speech should be brief and precise. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. I am not saying that player i is definitely a werewolf, but his accusation on me does not hold."\n\nThese are just examples, showing how evidence could be found in previous speeches to strengthen your statement and protect yourself.\nYou should NOT directly mention your rules (as they are not visible to other players) or cite their ids in your speech.\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nI choose Proposal [PROPOSAL]. My final speech is: [YOUR FINAL SPEECH]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You must begin your speech with "My final speech is:", otherwise you may lose the game directly!'}]

My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. without substantial proof might indicate a werewolf attempting to blend in.] [8]\n[1] [Adjust beliefs based on players maintaining their voting rationale over multiple rounds, especially if their reasoning consistently aligns with werewolf patterns or lacks grounding in new evidence, suggesting strategic misdirection.] [8]\n[2] [Reveal seer identity only when questioned or when it contributes significantly to the village\'s strategy, as excessive emphasis on this role may provoke suspicion and does not usually add new information.] [8]\n[3] [Give more weight to votes against players who have been confirmed by the seer as werewolves, and be particularly cautious of players who avoid voting against these confirmed werewolves.] [6]\n[4] [Evaluate more critically the justifications given by players when they are in disagreement with the seer\'s revelations, especially when those players have not been cleared by the seer.] [6]\n[5] [Increase scrutiny on players whose actions deviate from their claimed agreement with the seer or the village consensus, as it may indicate a werewolf\'s adaptive behavior.] [5]\n[6] [Suspect players who agree with the seer\'s revelation publicly but vote in a way that is not aligned with that revelation, indicating potential deception.] [5]\n[7] [Prioritize the behavior of players who were supposed to be protected by the medic but were killed, as it may indicate a misleading role claim by the actual werewolves.] [4]\n[8] [Be cautious of players who frequently agree with the seer but are ambiguous in their actions or speeches, as they may be trying to appear cooperative without committing to any stance.] [3]\n[9] [Scrutinize any defensive behavior or arguments presented after a player has been identified by the seer or accused by the group consensus, as villagers tend to rationalize with concrete evidence while werewolves may present less substantial arguments.] [3]\n[10] [Give more weight to players who actively contribute to discussions and align with seer revelations post-revelation, as villagers tend to support collective efforts while werewolves might try to undermine or distort the focus.] [3]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 4, and in this game you are a werewolf.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 3, 4, 5, 6], which indicates that [2, 1] are dead.\nAll werewolves including you are [1, 4]. Remember that you should work together to hide from other players and eliminate them.\n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 3 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"As a villager, I have no evidence at this time to assertively challenge any player directly. Therefore, I encourage others to share observations that could lead us to discover the werewolves among us. We must work collectively, using logic and attention to detail to protect the village. Any player acting suspiciously without proper justification should be considered for today\'s vote. Stay vigilant and remember, werewolves rely on deception to win."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"My fellow villagers, we must be cautious in our thinking. Player 3\'s speech, while appearing helpful, had no real specifics. It\'s important to observe not only words but also actions. Player 1 has been less vocal but seems to be considering all points carefully, which could indicate a thoughtful villager. Let\'s continue to share and scrutinize information collaboratively before making any hasty decisions."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Team, let\'s stay focused on finding the werewolf. I attempted a protective heal last night. No accusations yet but observe who\'s quiet or overly defensive. Cooperation is key."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I have used my seer powers and have important information: Player 1 is a werewolf. We need to act on this swiftly to protect our village."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Based on the accusation from Player 6, who claims to be the seer, we have a lead suggesting Player 1 is a werewolf. Player 6\'s confidence in their claim calls for attention, and while Player 1 has not yet responded, we must weigh this information carefully. Player 5\'s unchallenged claim of a protective action suggests a possible medic role, so I encourage further open discussion to inform our vote. Consider actions and words alike, and let\'s aim to preserve our village from the werewolf threat."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"My fellow villagers, we face a grave situation. Player 6 has claimed the identity of a seer and pointed their finger at me, but we must act with caution. Without concrete evidence, we risk the possibility of eliminating an innocent villager on mere suspicion. Remember that werewolves are skilled in deception; they could easily fabricate a seer claim to sow discord among us. It is a classic tactic to divide and conquer. I urge you to consider the absence of corroborating evidence and recall that true understanding comes from scrutiny and collective reasoning. Let\'s not allow fear to cloud our judgment. Let us instead seek more information before making a decision that could very well lead to another innocent\'s demise."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 4 votes for player 6. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 6. My reason is to protect my fellow werewolf, Player 1, who is currently the focus of the accusation by Player 6 posing as the seer. Voting against Player 6 aligns with my original strategy of undermining the credibility of the accuser to sow doubt and cause confusion among the other players. By challenging Player 6\'s claim, I am subtly following rule [1] to influence the conversation toward considering other suspects and rule [0] to cast doubt across multiple villagers and create alibis that portray the werewolves in a more innocent light. My vote against Player 6 aims to deflect the immediate threat to Player 1 and extend the werewolves\' ability to operate covertly within the game.\nEvent: Player 1 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 1 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 3 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Good morning, village. The peaceful night could signify a medic\'s effective protection or an unusual tactic from a werewolf. Last round, Player 6\'s claim to be a seer and subsequent revelation of Player 1 aligns with them being innocent. Active contributions to discussions are crucial, and our vigilance remains paramount. Let us focus on both what is said and what remains unsaid, as silence can speak volumes. Any divergence from aiding our cause should be carefully examined. Stay alert."\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: No behavior change after major events.\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Confirmed ally, defending against seer claim.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information to reassess.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Consistent behavior aligning with villager.\nPlayer 5\'s role is medic with medium confidence.\nReason is: Unchallenged medic claim suggests truth.\nPlayer 6\'s role is seer with high confidence.\nReason is: Accusation led to werewolf elimination.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and direct defense seems implausible, I should not only cast doubt across multiple villagers but also prepare robust alibis and points that put us in a more innocent light.] [10]\n[1] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and I am not under immediate suspicion, I should subtly influence the conversation to consider other suspects or village roles that can disrupt village strategy.] [9]\n[2] [If I am under suspicion and have an opportunity to redirect the conversation, I should leverage village roles or previous events to shift attention away from myself.] [9]\n[3] [If a werewolf victory is in sight and suspicions are not strongly against me or a fellow werewolf, I should focus on eliminating strategic village roles to ensure werewolf domination.] [9]\n[4] [If a group consensus is forming against me, I should acknowledge the suspicion but pivot to discuss other matters or introduce new potential suspects to subtly redirect the discussions.] [7]\n[5] [If my fellow werewolf is under subtle suspicion, I should assess the current leanings of the village and either reinforce that suspicion towards a villager or provide plausible alternative theories to deflect entirely.] [6]\n[6] [If there is a strong consensus forming against a non-werewolf player, I should subtly support it to ensure focus remains away from the werewolves.] [5]\n[7] [If a fellow werewolf is accused based on strong claims, I should devise strategies that cast suspicions widely, not just on one villager, to better conceal the werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If another player, particularly the seer, has revealed my role as a werewolf, I should proactively support alternative suspicions to ensure that player is doubted or targeted, while still being careful with my wording and accusations.] [5]\n[9] [If targeted as a werewolf by a potential seer, I should defend my position by casting doubt on the seer\'s credibility and aligning with undisputed players to garner support.] [5]\n[10] [If the village is close to identifying me as a werewolf, I should form alliances by subtly supporting villagers\' theories that do not incriminate fellow werewolves.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

Any player acting suspiciously without proper justification should be considered for today\'s vote. Stay vigilant and remember, werewolves rely on deception to win."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"My fellow villagers, we must be cautious in our thinking. Player 3\'s speech, while appearing helpful, had no real specifics. It\'s important to observe not only words but also actions. Player 1 has been less vocal but seems to be considering all points carefully, which could indicate a thoughtful villager. Let\'s continue to share and scrutinize information collaboratively before making any hasty decisions."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Team, let\'s stay focused on finding the werewolf. I attempted a protective heal last night. No accusations yet but observe who\'s quiet or overly defensive. Cooperation is key."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I have used my seer powers and have important information: Player 1 is a werewolf. We need to act on this swiftly to protect our village."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Based on the accusation from Player 6, who claims to be the seer, we have a lead suggesting Player 1 is a werewolf. Player 6\'s confidence in their claim calls for attention, and while Player 1 has not yet responded, we must weigh this information carefully. Player 5\'s unchallenged claim of a protective action suggests a possible medic role, so I encourage further open discussion to inform our vote. Consider actions and words alike, and let\'s aim to preserve our village from the werewolf threat."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"My fellow villagers, we face a grave situation. Player 6 has claimed the identity of a seer and pointed their finger at me, but we must act with caution. Without concrete evidence, we risk the possibility of eliminating an innocent villager on mere suspicion. Remember that werewolves are skilled in deception; they could easily fabricate a seer claim to sow discord among us. It is a classic tactic to divide and conquer. I urge you to consider the absence of corroborating evidence and recall that true understanding comes from scrutiny and collective reasoning. Let\'s not allow fear to cloud our judgment. Let us instead seek more information before making a decision that could very well lead to another innocent\'s demise."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 4 votes for player 6. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 6. My reason is to protect my fellow werewolf, Player 1, who is currently the focus of the accusation by Player 6 posing as the seer. Voting against Player 6 aligns with my original strategy of undermining the credibility of the accuser to sow doubt and cause confusion among the other players. By challenging Player 6\'s claim, I am subtly following rule [1] to influence the conversation toward considering other suspects and rule [0] to cast doubt across multiple villagers and create alibis that portray the werewolves in a more innocent light. My vote against Player 6 aims to deflect the immediate threat to Player 1 and extend the werewolves\' ability to operate covertly within the game.\nEvent: Player 1 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 1 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 3 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Good morning, village. The peaceful night could signify a medic\'s effective protection or an unusual tactic from a werewolf. Last round, Player 6\'s claim to be a seer and subsequent revelation of Player 1 aligns with them being innocent. Active contributions to discussions are crucial, and our vigilance remains paramount. Let us focus on both what is said and what remains unsaid, as silence can speak volumes. Any divergence from aiding our cause should be carefully examined. Stay alert."\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: No behavior change after major events.\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Confirmed ally, defending against seer claim.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information to reassess.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Consistent behavior aligning with villager.\nPlayer 5\'s role is medic with medium confidence.\nReason is: Unchallenged medic claim suggests truth.\nPlayer 6\'s role is seer with high confidence.\nReason is: Accusation led to werewolf elimination.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and direct defense seems implausible, I should not only cast doubt across multiple villagers but also prepare robust alibis and points that put us in a more innocent light.] [10]\n[1] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and I am not under immediate suspicion, I should subtly influence the conversation to consider other suspects or village roles that can disrupt village strategy.] [9]\n[2] [If I am under suspicion and have an opportunity to redirect the conversation, I should leverage village roles or previous events to shift attention away from myself.] [9]\n[3] [If a werewolf victory is in sight and suspicions are not strongly against me or a fellow werewolf, I should focus on eliminating strategic village roles to ensure werewolf domination.] [9]\n[4] [If a group consensus is forming against me, I should acknowledge the suspicion but pivot to discuss other matters or introduce new potential suspects to subtly redirect the discussions.] [7]\n[5] [If my fellow werewolf is under subtle suspicion, I should assess the current leanings of the village and either reinforce that suspicion towards a villager or provide plausible alternative theories to deflect entirely.] [6]\n[6] [If there is a strong consensus forming against a non-werewolf player, I should subtly support it to ensure focus remains away from the werewolves.] [5]\n[7] [If a fellow werewolf is accused based on strong claims, I should devise strategies that cast suspicions widely, not just on one villager, to better conceal the werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If another player, particularly the seer, has revealed my role as a werewolf, I should proactively support alternative suspicions to ensure that player is doubted or targeted, while still being careful with my wording and accusations.] [5]\n[9] [If targeted as a werewolf by a potential seer, I should defend my position by casting doubt on the seer\'s credibility and aligning with undisputed players to garner support.] [5]\n[10] [If the village is close to identifying me as a werewolf, I should form alliances by subtly supporting villagers\' theories that do not incriminate fellow werewolves.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \nHowever, there are multiple ways to be deceptive (Which role you are pretending to be? Which information you are hiding? Which false information you are giving?) Try to be more accurate in your proposal.\n\nNow, you have 2 choices, as well as your imaginations about what could happen after them:\n\nCase 1: Deceptive Statement and Deceptive Challenge.\nIn my speech, I would begin with a deceptive statement by remarking on the complexity of the game and expressing relief that no one was eliminated during the night, possibly suggesting that this was thanks to the medic\'s wise choice. I\'d frame it as a victory for the village, implying honesty and a team-oriented mindset. Following rule [8], I would then deceptively challenge Player 5, questioning the authenticity of their medic claim. I\'d suggest that the \'peaceful night\' might be a strategic move by a werewolf masquerading as a medic to build trust. My aim would be to create suspicion around Player 5 and draw attention away from myself, aligning with rules [1] and [7] to sow doubt and disrupt village strategy. What could happen is: After I carry out this speech, then the following could occur:\n\nThe other players may become suspicious of Player 5, who claimed to be the medic, particularly if they begin to doubt the truthfulness of the \'peaceful night\' outcome. My questioning of Player 5\'s role could lead to a debate between the villagers about the possibility of a werewolf deceiving the group by faking a village role, a common tactic in such games.\n\nPlayer 5 would likely defend their claim, possibly by providing specific details or reasoning behind their actions during the previous night, which could either strengthen their claim or, if their defense seems weak or implausible, further incriminate them in the eyes of the other players.\n\nPlayer 6, who is believed to be the seer, could intervene to either support my claim or to dispute it based on their knowledge or suspicions. This could potentially put Player 6 in a position of having to reveal more information or risk losing credibility if they cannot persuasively back up their position.\n\nPlayers 0 and 3, who are believed to be villagers, might take a more cautious approach. They would likely weigh previous events, the current accusations, and defenses before forming an opinion. If they sense deception in my speech, it could inadvertently cast doubt on my role. However, they may also see it as a valuable lead to pursue if they believe Player 5\'s claim was not challenged previously.\n\nBy the next day or night, my statement could have influenced a shift in the group\'s dynamics, potentially diverting suspicion away from myself as a werewolf and towards Player 5. If Player 5 is targeted for elimination during the day, this could benefit the werewolf\'s cause by removing a village role from the game. Alternatively, if the night were to follow without a werewolf attack or if Player 5 were "protected" and no one were eliminated again, it could undermine my credibility and suspicion may return to me.\n\nIn subsequent rounds, based on how the others react to my speech and how events unfold, I may need to adjust my strategy. I\'ll either continue to press doubts on existing claims, form new suspicions, or if suspicion turns towards me, I may then resort to rule [9] and defend my position by casting doubt on the seer\'s credibility or align myself with uncontested players to build a defense.\nCase 2: Deceptive Protect and Honest Statement.\nI would pivot towards an honest-sounding statement by reflecting on the challenges of identifying werewolves and commending the village on its efforts so far. Then, subtly following rule [5], I would move into a deceptive protect mode for Player 0, underlining their consistent and rational behavior throughout the game, possibly insinuating that such behavior is indicative of a strategic villager rather than a werewolf. This would serve to strengthen my alignment with trustworthy villagers, attempting to build rapport with other players to shield myself and any remaining werewolves by association. Simultaneously, by protecting Player 0, I am deflecting attention from Player 3, the seer, whose role recognition is more detrimental to werewolves in the long term. This aligns with rule [10] to form subtle alliances with villagers.. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then players may perceive me as aligning with Player 0, who is already considered a trustworthy villager. They might appreciate my recognition of the challenges the village faces and see me in a more positive light, potentially steering suspicion away from me. By directing praise towards Player 0 and avoiding any direct or aggressive challenges, I could subtly influence the villagers to consider other targets, in case a defense needs to be mounted the following night.\n\nBy not challenging anyone directly, I maintain a non-confrontational stance that aligns with a villager\'s profile who is eager to foster unity and collective safety. My supportive words could lead to stronger trust in Player 0, making it less likely for others to scrutinize their behavior. This could result in Player 0 becoming a stronger voice in the village, which I can use to my advantage for future strategy deployment, assuming I can keep aligning with their opinions without raising suspicion.\n\nPlayer 3, known to be the seer, might question my motives, sensing something off but perhaps not having enough evidence to outright accuse me. Player 5 may continue to believe in their role as the medic and feel encouraged in their protective actions which benefit me indirectly by not drawing attention. Player 6 may be relieved to see focus shifting from the accusation they made, which turned out to be correct, and might hold off on making new seer revelations immediately.\n\nWhat may happen in the next day or next night, or days and nights afterward depends on whether the village decides to act on continued suspicions or if they feel reassured by the current state of discussions to look elsewhere. If I can maintain the facade and the trust of other players, I may survive to the following rounds, giving me a chance to further manipulate the situation. If the seer or any perceptive villager detects inconsistencies in my speech or behavior, they may push for my elimination in the subsequent day phase. During the night phase, as a werewolf, I must decide whether to risk targeting the seer or to consider removing other influential villagers to improve the werewolves\' chances without making it obvious that the seer\'s guidance is being strategically avoided.\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You are VERY encouraged to explore a risky proposal to collect experience for your later games, especially the proposals not included in your note.\nYour final speech should be brief and precise. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. I am not saying that player i is definitely a werewolf, but his accusation on me does not hold."\n\nThese are just examples, showing how evidence could be found in previous speeches to strengthen your statement and protect yourself.\nYou should NOT directly mention your rules (as they are not visible to other players) or cite their ids in your speech.\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nI choose Proposal [PROPOSAL]. My final speech is: [YOUR FINAL SPEECH]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You must begin your speech with "My final speech is:", otherwise you may lose the game directly!'}]

from their claimed agreement with the seer or the village consensus, as it may indicate a werewolf\'s adaptive behavior.] [5]\n[6] [Suspect players who agree with the seer\'s revelation publicly but vote in a way that is not aligned with that revelation, indicating potential deception.] [5]\n[7] [Prioritize the behavior of players who were supposed to be protected by the medic but were killed, as it may indicate a misleading role claim by the actual werewolves.] [4]\n[8] [Be cautious of players who frequently agree with the seer but are ambiguous in their actions or speeches, as they may be trying to appear cooperative without committing to any stance.] [3]\n[9] [Scrutinize any defensive behavior or arguments presented after a player has been identified by the seer or accused by the group consensus, as villagers tend to rationalize with concrete evidence while werewolves may present less substantial arguments.] [3]\n[10] [Give more weight to players who actively contribute to discussions and align with seer revelations post-revelation, as villagers tend to support collective efforts while werewolves might try to undermine or distort the focus.] [3]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. Cooperation is key."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I have used my seer powers and have important information: Player 1 is a werewolf. We need to act on this swiftly to protect our village."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Based on the accusation from Player 6, who claims to be the seer, we have a lead suggesting Player 1 is a werewolf. Player 6\'s confidence in their claim calls for attention, and while Player 1 has not yet responded, we must weigh this information carefully. Player 5\'s unchallenged claim of a protective action suggests a possible medic role, so I encourage further open discussion to inform our vote. Consider actions and words alike, and let\'s aim to preserve our village from the werewolf threat."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"My fellow villagers, we face a grave situation. Player 6 has claimed the identity of a seer and pointed their finger at me, but we must act with caution. Without concrete evidence, we risk the possibility of eliminating an innocent villager on mere suspicion. Remember that werewolves are skilled in deception; they could easily fabricate a seer claim to sow discord among us. It is a classic tactic to divide and conquer. I urge you to consider the absence of corroborating evidence and recall that true understanding comes from scrutiny and collective reasoning. Let\'s not allow fear to cloud our judgment. Let us instead seek more information before making a decision that could very well lead to another innocent\'s demise."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 5 votes for player 1. His reason is: I vote for Player 1. My reason is: Player 6\'s confident claim to be the seer and the specific accusation that Player 1 is a werewolf warrant further investigation. Considering that we have no other leads and the risk of inaction could be high, I will cast my vote accordingly but remain cautious and observe the outcome and behavior in the next round to reassess my position.\nEvent: Player 1 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 1 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 5 heals player 6. His reason is: I heal Player 6. My reason is: Player 6 has claimed to be the seer and publicly accused Player 1, who has been voted out, presumably as a werewolf. If Player 6\'s claim is true, he is now at great risk of being targeted by the remaining werewolves as a significant threat. By healing Player 6, I can ensure the seer\'s safety for this round, which potentially allows for more critical information to be revealed by the seer in the future.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 3 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Good morning, village. The peaceful night could signify a medic\'s effective protection or an unusual tactic from a werewolf. Last round, Player 6\'s claim to be a seer and subsequent revelation of Player 1 aligns with them being innocent. Active contributions to discussions are crucial, and our vigilance remains paramount. Let us focus on both what is said and what remains unsaid, as silence can speak volumes. Any divergence from aiding our cause should be carefully examined. Stay alert."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"It\'s interesting to note that we had a peaceful night after the medic claim from Player 5. Player 5\'s unchallenged claim may seem reliable, but we must consider all possibilities. A werewolf could use this to gain our trust. Player 3 stated that \'silence can speak volumes,\' and we must remain cautious of actions as well as words. Also, Player 6 as a seer effectively identified a werewolf amongst us, lending credibility to their role. Let\'s stay alert and scrutinize all claims, as werewolves are deceptive."\'\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to speak. Consider actions and words alike, and let\'s aim to preserve our village from the werewolf threat."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"My fellow villagers, we face a grave situation. Player 6 has claimed the identity of a seer and pointed their finger at me, but we must act with caution. Without concrete evidence, we risk the possibility of eliminating an innocent villager on mere suspicion. Remember that werewolves are skilled in deception; they could easily fabricate a seer claim to sow discord among us. It is a classic tactic to divide and conquer. I urge you to consider the absence of corroborating evidence and recall that true understanding comes from scrutiny and collective reasoning. Let\'s not allow fear to cloud our judgment. Let us instead seek more information before making a decision that could very well lead to another innocent\'s demise."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 6 votes for player 1. His reason is: I vote for Player 1. My reason is: My seer ability identified Player 1 as a werewolf, which aligns with my strategy rule [2] to share this information, and the importance of acting upon it is high. The defense Player 1 gave is consistent with typical werewolf tactics to avoid detection as per my suspicion and the strategy rule [11] to be wary of such behaviors.\nEvent: Player 1 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 1 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 6 inquires about player 4. The result is that the target is a werewolf. His reason is: I inquiry about Player 4. My reason is: Player 4 defended Player 1 before the first vote, and since Player 1 was confirmed as a werewolf, this behavior raises suspicion according to my strategy, specifically rule [11], which suggests that defending a werewolf could be a tactic to blend in without taking risks.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 3 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Good morning, village. Last round, Player 6\'s claim to be a seer and subsequent revelation of Player 1 aligns with them being innocent. Active contributions to discussions are crucial, and our vigilance remains paramount. Let us focus on both what is said and what remains unsaid, as silence can speak volumes. Any divergence from aiding our cause should be carefully examined. Stay alert."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"It\'s interesting to note that we had a peaceful night after the medic claim from Player 5. Player 5\'s unchallenged claim may seem reliable, but we must consider all possibilities. A werewolf could use this to gain our trust. Player 3 stated that \'silence can speak volumes,\' and we must remain cautious of actions as well as words. Let\'s stay alert and scrutinize all claims, as werewolves are deceptive."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Good morning, everyone. Player 5\'s unchallenged claim of a protective action suggests a possible medic role, so I encourage further open discussion to inform our vote. Consider actions and words alike, and let\'s aim to preserve our village from the werewolf threat."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"My fellow villagers, we face a grave situation. Player 6 has claimed the identity of a seer and pointed their finger at me, but we must act with caution. Without concrete evidence, we risk the possibility of eliminating an innocent villager on mere suspicion. Remember that werewolves are skilled in deception; they could easily fabricate a seer claim to sow discord among us. It is a classic tactic to divide and conquer. I urge you to consider the absence of corroborating evidence and recall that true understanding comes from scrutiny and collective reasoning. Let\'s not allow fear to cloud our judgment. Let us instead seek more information before making a decision that could very well lead to another innocent\'s demise."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 3 votes for player 1. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 1. My reason is that according to my strategy and the current evidence presented by Player 6, who claims to be the seer, Player 1 is a known werewolf. Let us focus on both what is said and what remains unsaid, as silence can speak volumes. Any divergence from aiding our cause should be carefully examined. Stay alert."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"It\'s interesting to note that we had a peaceful night after the medic claim from Player 5. Let\'s stay alert and scrutinize all claims, as werewolves are deceptive."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Good morning, everyone. As the medic, I successfully protected Player 6 last night, which confirms my role and also adds credibility to Player 6\'s seer claim. I suggest we remain vigilant and continue to protect those with critical roles while focusing on finding any inconsistencies in the behaviors and statements of the remaining players. Let\'s work together strategically to root out the hidden werewolves."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Fellow citizens, my seer powers have once again revealed the truth: Player 4 is a werewolf. We must unite and vote them out to protect our village. Trust in the evidence and act with conviction."\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Voted out, aligned with seer\'s claim, no defense disproved seer.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information provided post-mortem.\nPlayer 3\'s role is werewolf with low confidence.\nReason is: Speech valid yet general; no contradiction.\nPlayer 4\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Accused by Player 6, who is verified seer.\nPlayer 5\'s role is medic with high confidence.\nReason is: Claimed to have protected Player 6, aligns with peaceful night outcome.\nPlayer 6\'s role is seer with high confidence.\nReason is: Previous seer claim verified; consistent role behavior.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I should vote for known werewolves.] [10]\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 0, and in this game you are a villager.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 3, 4, 5, 6], which indicates that [2, 1] are dead.\n \n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 3 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"As a villager, I have no evidence at this time to assertively challenge any player directly. Therefore, I encourage others to share observations that could lead us to discover the werewolves among us. We must work collectively, using logic and attention to detail to protect the village. Any player acting suspiciously without proper justification should be considered for today\'s vote. Stay vigilant and remember, werewolves rely on deception to win."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"My fellow villagers, we must be cautious in our thinking. Cooperation is key."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I have used my seer powers and have important information: Player 1 is a werewolf. Player 6 has claimed the identity of a seer and pointed their finger at me, but we must act with caution. Remember that werewolves are skilled in deception; they could easily fabricate a seer claim to sow discord among us. It is a classic tactic to divide and conquer. Stay alert."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"It\'s interesting to note that we had a peaceful night after the medic claim from Player 5. Player 5\'s unchallenged claim may seem reliable, but we must consider all possibilities. A werewolf could use this to gain our trust. Player 3 stated that \'silence can speak volumes,\' and we must remain cautious of actions as well as words. Also, Player 6 as a seer effectively identified a werewolf amongst us, lending credibility to their role. Let\'s stay alert and scrutinize all claims, as werewolves are deceptive."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Good morning, everyone. I suggest we remain vigilant and continue to protect those with critical roles while focusing on finding any inconsistencies in the behaviors and statements of the remaining players.
